entry.title: Obama Takes To Dance Floor In Kenya
Obama and African leaders to consider sanctions in South Sudan's civil war
entry.summary: The presidents of Uganda and Kenya, the prime minister of Ethiopia, the chairwoman of the African Union and the foreign minister of Sudan are all expected to attend the meeting in Addis Ababa.

entry.title: Obama says Kenya at crossroads between 'peril and promise'
Obama pushes Kenya to root out corruption
entry.summary: "Because of Kenya's progress - because of your potential - you can build your future right here, right now," Obama told the crowd of 4,500 packed into a sports arena in the capital of Nairobi.

entry.title: Obama urges Kenya to use tough past to guide its future
entry.summary:
On the final day of his visit in Kenya, Obama laid out his vision for Kenya's future and broad themes of U.S.-Kenya relations.

President Barack Obama delivers a speech at the Safaricom Indoor Arena in the Kasarani area of Nairobi, Kenya Sunday, July 26, 2015.

entry.title: Obama urges Kenya to use past to guide future
President Barack Obama to end historic Kenya visit with national address
entry.summary:
The president's late father was born and is buried in Kenya, and its people have waited for years for the chance to welcome Mr Obama back as president.

He made history by becoming the first sitting American president to visit Kenya when he arrived late on Friday.

entry.title: Obama chides Kenya on gay rights, ready for closer security work
entry.summary: Obama also said during his first visit as president to his father's homeland that Kenya had to tackle corruption by showing it was prosecuting culprits, saying it would spur growth.

entry.title: Obama, Kenya leader agree on terror, split on gays
entry.summary: "Kenya is leading the way," Mr. Obama said.

entry.title: Obama chides Kenya on gay rights, ready for closer security work
entry.summary: President Barack Obama told Kenya the United States was ready to work more closely in the battle against Somalia's Islamist group al Shabaab, but chided his host on gay rights and said no African state should discriminate over sexuality.

entry.title: In Kenya, Obama blends blunt messages with warm reflections
entry.summary: President Barack Obama mixed blunt messages to Kenya's leaders on gay rights, corruption and counterterrorism Saturday with warm reflections on his family ties to a nation that considers him a local son.

entry.title: In Kenya, Obama blends blunt messages with warm reflections
entry.summary:
Obama did little to paper over policy differences with Kenya's government, most notably on gay rights.

Obama also pushed Kenya to tighten its counterterrorism practices, which human rights group say have resulted in serious abuses.

entry.title: In Kenya, Obama blends blunt messages with warm reflections
entry.summary: A number of Kenyan politicians and religious leaders had warned Obama that any overtures on gay rights would not be welcomed in Kenya, where gay sex is punishable by up to 14 years in prison.

entry.title: The Latest: Obama warns corruption may thwart Kenya's growth
entry.summary:
President Barack Obama is warning that corruption may be the biggest impediment to Kenya's growth and opportunities in the future.

Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta says gay rights are a "nonissue" in Kenya and that the issue is not a priority.

Obama is speaking in a joint news conference in Nairobi, Kenya, with Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta.

entry.title: Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary: U.S. President Barack Obama, left, stands next to Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta, 2nd left, as the Kenya Air Force military band passes by, at State House in Nairobi, Kenya Saturday, July 25, 2015.

entry.title: Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary: U.S. President Barack Obama inspects the honor guard after arriving to meet with Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta at State House in Nairobi, Kenya, Saturday, July 25, 2015.

entry.title: White House Notebook: Kenya says it's no 'hotbed of terror' as Obama opens visit
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenyans eager to have their country in the spotlight during President Barack Obama's visit have been irked by a news report describing the East African nation as a "hotbed of terror."

entry.title: White House Notebook: Obama faces 'family politics' in Kenya
entry.summary:
President Uhuru Kenyatta even joined in, telling attendees at the Global Entrepreneurship Summit that they will find Kenya to be "a hotbed of vibrant culture, spectacular natural beauty, and a wonderful people with infinite possibility."

Kenya has struggled to contain the threat from al-Shabab militants based in neighboring Somalia.

Al-Shabab, a group linked to al-Qaeda, has conducted major attacks in Kenya, including the 2013 attack on Nairobi's Westgate mall and an April attack in Garissa town that killed nearly 150 people.

entry.title: Barack Obama, in Kenya, says discriminating against gays erodes freedom
entry.summary: He said he hoped Obama's visit would help change the narrative about Kenya and Africa.

entry.title: Obama at Kenya business summit: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary: U.S. President Barack Obama heralded Africa as a continent "on the move" Saturday as he opened a U.S.-sponsored business summit in Kenya, the East African nation where he has family ties.

entry.title: Barack Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary:
Obama's visit to Kenya - the first by a sitting US president - has been highly anticipated in a nation that views him as a local son.

The president's late father was born in Kenya and many family members still live here, including his elderly step-grandmother.

entry.title: Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
Obama in Kenya: 'Africa is on the move'
entry.summary: The Kenya attack killed more than 200 Kenyans and 12 Americans at the embassy.

entry.title: Kenya welcomes President Obama
Kenya bids 'welcome home' to President Obama
entry.summary: President Barack Obama poses for a photograph with Joan Wamaitha, 8, who gave him flowers on his arrival at the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi, Kenya.

entry.title: Kenya bids 'welcome home' to President Obama
entry.summary: Obama's father was born here in 1936 and died in 1982, and Obama is widely viewed as a son of Kenya.

entry.title: Obama's link to Kenya: A father he barely knew
entry.summary: Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta, left, watches as President Barack Obama signs a guest book after arriving at Kenyatta International Airport, on Friday, July 24, 2015, in Nairobi, Kenya.

entry.title: Obama's link to Kenya: A father he barely knew
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya - Barack Obama's link to Kenya, where he began his first visit as U.S. president Friday, is a father he barely knew but whose influence can nonetheless be seen in his son's presidency.

entry.title: Obama's link to Kenya: A father he barely knew
entry.summary: The president's father, Barack Obama Sr., left Kenya as a young man to study at the University of Hawaii.

entry.title: Kenya bids ?welcome home? to President Obama
entry.summary: President Barack Obama arrives Friday in Kenya, the ancestral homeland that has waited impatiently for a visit from the U.S. president since he was first elected to office.

entry.title: Obama's visit to Kenya, Ethiopia sparks concerns over human rights and governance issues
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON - President Barack Obama's trip to Kenya and Ethiopia is drawing fresh criticism that the two countries are heavy-handed on human rights and basic democratic freedoms.

Obama will become the first sitting U.S. president to visit Kenya, his ancestral homeland, when he arrives Friday to attend a business summit and meetings with President Uhuru Kenyatta.

The letter to Obama said he should put the "pressing human rights concerns" in Kenya and Ethiopia "at the forefront of your discussions."

The letter expressed concern that both countries are using national security concerns to stifle the media as well as civic participation and, in Kenya, to crack down on Somali refugees who have fled the instability in their home country.

"But what is consistent is, where ever we go, whether it is in Africa, or elsewhere in the world where we have such concerns, we raise them directly and clearly, both in public and in private, and we will do that as we always do, when we visit Kenya and Ethiopia," Rice said Wednesday while previewing the trip for reporters.

entry.title: As he heads to Africa, Obama's electricity plan in jeopardy
entry.summary: FILE - In this Saturday, Aug. 26, 2006 file photo, then U.S. Senator Barack Obama meets with his step-grandmother Sarah Obama at his father's house in Kogelo, western Kenya.

entry.title: As he heads to Africa, Obama's electricity plan in jeopardy
entry.summary: Although this week's trip to Kenya and Ethiopia will be Obama's third to sub-Saharan Africa as president, his global agenda has been largely focused on Asia and the Middle East.

entry.title: White House dismisses Kenya release of Obama schedule
entry.summary: The White House had announced earlier this year that Obama would travel to Kenya to attend a Global Entrepreneurship Summit.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary: On Friday, July 24, 2015 Obama is due to arrive in Kenya, the country of his father's birth, for the first time since he was a U.S. senator in 2006, and the first stop on his two-nation African tour in which he will also visit Ethiopia.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary:
This week, Obama will make his first visit to Kenya as U.S. president, a trip that will bear little resemblance to the 1988 one, when he arrived aboard commercial flight and his luggage got lost.

Even as a U.S. senator, he was greeted by cheering crowds when he made his last visit to Kenya, in 2006.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary: President Barack Obama is due to make his first trip as president to Kenya later in the month, the country of his father's birth, to attend the Global Entrepreneurship Summit, which brings together business leaders, international organizations and governments.

entry.title: Obama and Kenya: 1st trip to father's homeland as president
entry.summary: A chef walks past a cardboard cutout of President Barack Obama in the entrance way of the Cafe Deli coffee shop in downtown Nairobi, Kenya, Wednesday, July 22, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya prepares to welcome Obama to the country where his father was born
entry.summary:
Welcome to Kenya.

In Kenya, Obama will address a meeting on international entrepreneurship and hold talks with Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta, who has said trade and security are key topics.

entry.title: Kenya prepares to welcome President Obama to the country where his father was born
entry.summary: Obama is scheduled to arrive in Kenya on Friday, the first stop on his two-nation African tour in which he will also visit Ethiopia.

entry.title: Kenya president says talks with Obama to focus on extremism
entry.summary: Kenya has been working closely with American security agencies in the fight against extremism and the meeting with Obama will further strengthen this cooperation, Kenyatta said.

entry.title: Kenya president says talks with Obama to focus on extremism
entry.summary: Kenya is battling a wave of extremist attacks by al-Qaida-linked al-Shabab militants from Somalia that has killed more than 400 people since October 2011 when the country sent troops into Somalia to fight the militants.

entry.title: Kenya president says talks with Obama to focus on extremism
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta says the fight against extremism will be the key topic of talks with U.S. President Barack Obama, who will be visiting the country of his father later this week.

entry.title: Shoppers return to Kenya's Westgate mall nearly two years after terrorist attack
entry.summary: The event came less than a week before US President Barack Obama's planned visit to Kenya, when he will underscore American support for the war against al-Shabab.

entry.title: Kenya mall reopens after 2013 terror attack
Kenya's Westgate shopping mall reopens
Al-Shabaab jihadists linked to Kenya attacks 'killed by drone'
entry.summary: In April, four Shebab militants massacred 148 people at the Garissa University in Kenya's northeast, in what was the group's deadliest single attack to date.

entry.title: Kenya press freedom rapidly deteriorating, rights group says
entry.summary:
The deteriorating climate for the media comes at a time when press scrutiny and public discussion are essential for continued development of Kenya's democracy and economy, the report said.

Also needing press scrutiny, according to the report, is the situation for Kenya's deputy president who is under indictment from the International Criminal Court, although similar charges were dropped against the president.

entry.title: Kenya press freedom rapidly deteriorating, rights group says
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) " Press freedom is deteriorating in Kenya as a result of government legislation, threats and attacks, a media rights group said Wednesday.

entry.title: Nairobi mall to re-open 2 years after extremist attack
entry.summary:
But Kenya has rebounded from the violence, said Nairobi Governor Evans Kidero, who toured the mall on Tuesday.

Nairobi is safe and U.S .President Barack Obama's visit to the country later this month is testimony to Kenya's security, said Kidero who urged shoppers to turn out Saturday for the re-opening.
